author: 8BrickMario
title: Is this a "do" or a "D'oh"nt?
review:
To be honest, my primary reason for getting this pack was because it was a level pack, and thus, beneficial to completion. Was I pleasantly surprised?

Box/Instructions

 

Parts

The parts here are pretty nice, with the pink and lavender being less common colors in non-minidoll themes. The Buzz Cola can and soda top are also nice parts.

Minifigures

Homer here has been seen before, but he's still a good representation of the character. 

The build

Fairly easy, with the most interesting technique being the cab of the car.

The completed model

The two builds look pretty nice, with both being recognizable models. I think my favorite build is the Mecha-Homer upgrade of the television. So creative!

Gameplay

...and this is where it falls short for me.

Due to the characters I own, Homer is completely redundant to me. His abilities are to break glass with a sonic belch, and to grow with rage to use super strength. I find Wonder Woman and the Doctor to cover these abilities, with more on both sides. 

The car itself is actually pretty nice, as it's able to pull down weak walls with purple hooks without being upgraded (unlike the Batmobile), but I don't find myself using it much.

The television's main function is to distract enemies so you can get past. Again, not incredibly useful. 

The level itself is okay, being a recreation of "The Mysterious Voyage of Homer". If you have the TARDIS, there's a cameo from another classic animated sitcom. The level itself is nice due to its dreamlike environment, but like the Back to the Future pack, I would have preferred an original story. 

The Adventure World that owning Homer gave me access to is pretty nice. I like the softer, more cartoony style of Springfield, and there are all of the important locations. I've noticed a bizarre trend with these worlds to include tunnel systems and underwater areas, but they just add to the exploration. 

Overall opinion

This is probably the weakest of all of the Level Packs, offering no exclusive gameplay mechanics, and having the least useful character and models. If you're not concerned about completing all of the levels, I'd recommend getting Bart or Krusty instead.

author: Odeinoichus
title: An Almost Perfect Addition.
review:
Set #71202 The Simpsons Level Pack: This second Level Pack from LEGO Dimensions features the longest running Animated Sitcom in television history. Homer Simpson joins the party and the dimensional breaking hijinks along with his favorite family automobile and television set. And unlike the first pack I reviewed this one offers up a longer level, unfortunately there is a slight flaw in this pack, and it’s in regards to what Fox allowed Warner Brother’s to use in their digital content. We’ll get to those issues later, for now let’s move on to the rest of the review.

Packaging

Please see my Back to the Future Level Pack review for a detailed discussion of the Packaging. Homer’s Packaging is standard Level Pack design with images of the models, digital world and character design on the front and back.

Parts

This set features a printed Itchy & Scratchy Television screen, buzz cola can and lid and a lot of purple and pink elements as well as a printed television remote control. Three tags are also included, two blank and one character tag for Homer Simpson.

Minifigures

Homer Simpson: Homer shares his parts with those found in the CMF Series 1 and the Simpson’s House set, minus the head which was different in the House set. His accessory is a Buzz Cola can, because Duff represents alcohol and cannot be used, naturally.

The build

Homer’s Car: What can I say about this build? It’s a very well done miniature scaled model of the Simpsons’ classic Pink Car, much like the DeLorean they went all out when designing the model and it shows as this vehicle can roll on four wheels perfectly.

The Homercraft: This disassembles the car into a hover craft style vehicle, the build once again relies on the exact same parts and as is typical with the secondary models in the set you need to get them digitally either by using the game to access the unlocked instructions after spending studs to upgrade the vehicle, or by going online and looking it up if you just want to see what this model looks like.

The SubmaHomer: This third build is making a submersible craft out of a hovercraft and… yeah… it’s something else I’ll say that. The build is relatively simple to follow along with, and uses all the same parts as the car only in a different configuration. LEGO did a good job making these designs incorporate all of the same parts so you don’t have to leave any off when building them.

Taunt-O-Vision: It’s a Television set, you’re building a Television set… I mean I guess that’s nice and all, but honestly there isn’t much to discuss about this build, aside from the fact that it is a rather large model compared to a Minifigure.

Blast Cam: Here’s where things start to get a bit more creative and whacky, this build is making some kind of laser shooting camera… as far as I can tell just by looking at it. It’s quite fun to build and looks fairly impressive for what it is.

The MechaHomer: This final alternative build is a giant mechanical suit… or at least it’s trying to be, it’s using all the parts from the Television to make this thing and the build is relatively straight forward without any difficult steps. It’s pretty creative and off the wall, much better than what they tried to do with the Hoverboard accessory.

The completed model

Homer’s Car: This original model is a very impressive looking version of Homer’s primary vehicle. The car model is greatly designed and allows for fun playability on and off the Toy Pad.

The Homercraft: This alternate model is a bit lacking, but it works serviceably for what it is. I believe the design in virtual world is slightly more impressive than the physical representation of it.

The SubmaHomer: Not a bad looking submarine using the same parts as the car. I will admit though I haven’t rebuilt any of the primary models in physical form yet, I follow along with the instructions, but I haven’t actually built any of them. They look great though, for what the designers were aiming at with these figures.

Taunt-O-Vision: This is a really fun looking model for The Simpsons television set, it also includes a television remote. Overall though it’s a bit useless as a model to play with outside of the virtual world, it looks better as a display model than something to play with.

Blast Cam: This re-make of the television is a really funny looking model design, but it does try to make this thing look like an attack camera that Homer has stolen from Professor Frink.

The MechaHomer: This is absolutely the oddest looking model out of the entire bunch. And honestly it’s the weakest idea out of the entire set. It doesn’t really fit too well as something Simpsons related, it’s just odd-ball whacky cartoon inspired, like something out of Looney Tunes or something. Could be worse though.

The Digital Content

The Level & Adventure World: This Level is a longer experience than Back to the Future. Using one of the well-known and enjoyable early season Simpsons episodes for the basis of the level, we find a lot of interesting things to do and explore as you experience the famous Chili Cook-Off Insanity Peppers episode of The Simpsons.

Archive Footage was used for the dialogue in The Simpsons, thus Johnny Cash became a character in LEGO Dimensions as Homer’s Spirit Guide. The level is very detailed and full of fun references, unfortunately because Archival Footage was used there are no new lines from Dan Castellaneta, and as I may have mentioned in the Starter Pack review, the Theme song is absent. Instead a sound-alike theme was used for the Level and the Adventure World and it just sounds awful. I mean it’s trying to be in keeping with the show, but damn does it come off as grating and annoying.

Also none of the other characters from Springfield get any dialogue lines, Marge, Bart, Lisa, Maggie, Mr. Burns, Smithers, anybody not voiced by Dan Castellaneta is not allowed to use archival footage and so effectively the Town of Springfield is completely mute. Krusty, Abe, Diamond Joe Quimby and Homer are the only characters with lines, we don’t even get to hear Apu’s famous Thank You, Come Again… it is a huge let-down considering there are a lot of fans of the Simpsons and folks would have probably enjoyed this level and adventure world a lot better if it was as lively and enjoyable as the actual cartoon show.

Speaking of the Adventure World it is vast, you can travel the suburbs of Springfield, stop off at the Elementary School, Town Hall, Mr. Burns’ Mansion, the Power Plant, Krustyland and a host of other areas including some fun references to early Simpsons Episodes including The Monorail as the Tracks still standing are seen circling the town and even under the water you’ll find some interesting nods if you’re a fan. I’d suggest muting the world though or swapping to a different track using the Jukebox because after hours of exploring this Adventure World you’ll be sick and tired of that fake knock-off Simpsons Theme song.

Vehicle & Character Abilities: Homer’s virtual abilities include Sonar Smash, allowing him to burp away glass objects, Big Transform, making him turn into Giant Homer… I’m not sure if this is referencing something, but honestly it could be. And of course as Giant Homer he can access and smash Cracked LEGO Objects.

Homer’s Car has access to Accelerator Switches, as is the case with most ground vehicles, and the Tow Bar ability. Switching to the Homercraft gives you the ability to sail on water while the SubmaHomer dives under water and can destroy Silver LEGO objects.

His Taunt-O-Vision can blow up Silver LEGO Objects and has the unique ability to Taunt Enemies, which basically means it attracts them. The Blast Cam can be ridden like a turret and operates as a Special Weapon, which I believe means it grants you more attack power, the MechaHomer allows you to destroy Gold LEGO Objects, overall a sadly weak number of virtual abilities that makes this particular set of in-game models rather pointless aside from the point where you build it inside the Simpsons Level.

Overall opinion

If you’re looking to 100% everything in this game then this Level Pack is required to unlock the digital content, while Bart and Krusty can unlock the Adventure World, the unique Level is only available with Homer, so I’d say you could skip the two Fun Packs and just go with this one for your 100% complete game file in LEGO Dimensions Year 1.

I am really disappointed that Fox and the licensing deal with them through Warner Brothers for LEGO Dimensions omitted certain key elements, Bart and most of the rest of the characters being Mute means we have to listen to Homer exclusively and his lines just aren’t funny enough on their own to justify this. On top of that the Mock Theme is terrible, it’s a bouncy up-beat tune that sounds like nails on a chalkboard after thirty minutes and it will take you at least that long to get through every puzzle and trick in the Level, then you’ve got an hour’s worth of exploring to do in the Adventure World, and unlike with Back to the Future they didn’t include different music tracks, just the one annoying fake Simpsons Theme for the duration. A terrible licensing deal, but what can you expect where greed is concerned.

Other than that complaint I find the set itself pretty enjoyable and the digital content does include a lot to see and do for fans of The Simpsons. All-in-all I can mildly recommend this one for that reason alone, if Dimensions doesn’t interest you in the slightest you won’t be missing out much on anything should you choose to skip this one.
